summary:
# Daily AI Newsletter Digest - 10/12/2025

## ğŸ”¥ Top Stories
- OpenAI reports strong growth in enterprise use of its tools, with ChatGPT message volume rising eightfold since November 2024, and 36% of U.S. businesses using enterprise AI tools now choosing ChatGPT Enterprise.
- Google plans to release AI-powered glasses in 2026, with two styles planned: audio-only frames for hands-free AI access and display versions with in-lens screens for navigation and translations.
- President Trump plans to sign an executive order limiting states from creating their own AI regulation, establishing a national "AI Litigation Task Force" to challenge existing state AI laws and push for national standards.

## ğŸ¤– AI Models & Research
- OpenAI released a comprehensive report on the state of enterprise AI, highlighting its adoption and benefits, including saving workers 40-60 minutes a day.
- Researchers from King Faisal University developed a lightweight Gaussian Process-Based Visual Servoing system for autonomous wheelchair sidewalk navigation using a simple camera, a Raspberry Pi, and an actuator.
- Opus 4.5, a new AI model, achieved 80.9% on SWE-bench Verified, outperforming other models like Sonnet 4.5 and GPT-5.1-Codex-Max, and uses 76% fewer output tokens than Sonnet 4.5.

## ğŸ› ï¸ Tools & Products
- Claude Code is now available in Slack, enabling developers to run coding sessions directly from threads, and integrates AI deeper into team collaboration.
- LlamaSheets allows for the automation of spreadsheet analysis using coding agents to extract clean data from messy Excel files.
- LlamaIndex offers one-click deployment of production-ready agent workflows, and provides various tools and features for AI and tech development.
- Lovart's Nano Banana Pro was upgraded with Touch Edit, a canvas-first control system for precise AI design editing.

## ğŸ“° Industry News
- Paramount launched a $108.4 billion hostile takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, calling Netflix's existing $83 billion offer "inferior" and warning it would face long, messy regulatory hurdles.
- NVIDIA's H200 AI chip sales to China will be allowed with a 25% revenue cut for the US.
- Meta acquired AI startup Limitless, which will stop selling its AI pendant device and end support after one year, and will expand its AI wearables team.

## ğŸ“š Resources & Learning
- Mindstream is offering a bundle of 5 in-demand money-making guides as an early Christmas present to its subscribers, including 3 AI guides and 2 wealth builder guides.
- A free bonus guide, "30 CREATIVE WAYS TO USE AI FOR BUSINESS OPTIMIZATION," is offered to subscribers who reply with "Biz" to the email.
- The Skilled Coder newsletter discusses the challenges of logging 1 million events per second without slowing down a system and provides an example architecture diagram for a scalable logging system.

Total Newsletters: 12

## TAAFT - There's An AI For That

### Key Highlights
- Trump reverses China chip ban, allowing Nvidia and AMD to sell certain chips to approved Chinese customers.
- ChatGPT usage surges 320Ã—, with 36% of US companies now using it at work.
- OpenAI builds a "truth serum" for models to confess when they've lied, hallucinated, or gamed the system.
- Gartner warns enterprises to block AI browsers like ChatGPT Atlas and Perplexity Comet due to irreversible data loss risks.

### Detailed Points
- The newsletter covers various AI developments, including Trump's reversal of the China chip ban, which will allow Nvidia and AMD to sell their H200 and other chips to approved Chinese customers.
- ChatGPT's usage has increased significantly, with complex reasoning token usage shooting up 320Ã—, and 36% of US companies now using it at work.
- OpenAI is working on a "truth serum" for its models, which will train them to confess when they've provided false information.
- Gartner has warned enterprises to block AI browsers like ChatGPT Atlas and Perplexity Comet due to the risk of irreversible data loss.
- Other notable developments include the launch of Claude Code, a coding agent that can be integrated into Slack, and the mapping of a Chinese naval base using satellite technology.
- The newsletter also mentions several AI tools, including Lessie AI, BeFreed, VoiceType.com, ChatPlayground AI, and Quicklogo.
- Additionally, it covers notable resources like Cloaked, which scans the web to see who has your data, and Sensay, which stops knowledge loss at offboarding with AI interviews.
- The newsletter also includes a prompt of the day, "Productivity Journaling Partner," which helps plan and review daily activities with clarity.

newsletters.summary:
## The Rundown AI

### Key Highlights
- OpenAI released its first-ever enterprise report, highlighting significant productivity gains among business users, with 75% of surveyed workers reporting improved output speed or quality.
- Google announced plans to enter the AI glasses market in 2026, partnering with Samsung, Warby Parker, and Gentle Monster.
- Anthropic introduced Claude Code to Slack, enabling developers to delegate coding tasks directly from the platform.
- Lovart upgraded Nano Banana Pro with Touch Edit, a canvas-first control system for precise AI design editing.

### Detailed Points
- **OpenAI Enterprise Report**: The report is based on anonymized data from over 1 million workplace accounts and an AI adoption survey across 100 enterprises. Key findings include:
  - 75% of workers reported improved output speed or quality.
  - 75% can now handle tasks they couldn't before.
  - Top 5% performers send 6x more messages than the median.
  - Top coders show a 17x difference in productivity.
  - ChatGPT business users save 40-60 minutes daily on average, with power users reporting gains of over 10 hours per week.
- **Google AI Glasses**: Google's entry into the AI glasses market is slated for 2026, with two styles planned: audio-only frames for hands-free AI access and display versions with in-lens screens for navigation and translations.
- **Anthropic & Slack**: The integration of Claude Code into Slack allows developers to tag @Claude in chat threads to initiate coding tasks, utilizing context from the thread for input and automatically posting progress updates back to the thread.
- **Lovart Nano Banana Pro**: The Touch Edit feature enables point-and-edit control, combining parts from multiple reference images, and maintaining consistency across revisions without requiring extensive prompt rewriting.
- **AI Training**: A tutorial is available on using ChatGPT to improve thinking patterns by breaking out of circular thinking and generating creative solutions through structured questioning.
- **Community Workflows**: A reader, Leroy P., shared how he uses Google Gemini to streamline end-of-year accounts for a small charity, significantly reducing workload and increasing accuracy.
- **News, Guides & Events**: Links to previous newsletters and guides, including those on using ChatGPT for thinking patterns and the latest in AI news.

## TLDR Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has paused side projects for 8 weeks to focus on improving ChatGPT.
- Google plans to launch AI-powered glasses in 2026.
- The cost of building software has dropped significantly with the advent of agentic coding.
- Waymo has crossed 450,000 weekly paid rides, widening its lead on Tesla.

### Detailed Points
- OpenAI is set to release a new model this week and another in January with better images, improved speed, and a better personality.
- Google's AI glasses will be built on top of Android XR in collaboration with Samsung, Gentle Monster, and Warby Parker.
- Eli Lilly has partnered with Nvidia to build an AI supercomputer and wants to position itself as a technology company.
- Tesla's Holiday Update allows users to put Grok in charge of mapping out directions.
- Nvidia's growth appears to be held up by a belief that there's a need for more GPUs.
- Apple chip chief Johny Srouji has told staff that he is staying at the company for now.
- Paramount Skydance is launching a hostile bid to buy Warner Bros. Discovery.

newsletters.summary:
## Superhuman Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- The "Slop Evader" web browser extension has been launched to help users avoid AI-generated text, images, and videos by only returning web results that were published before November 30th, 2022.
- President Trump plans to sign an executive order limiting states from creating their own AI regulation, establishing a national "AI Litigation Task Force" to challenge existing state AI laws and push for national standards.
- Google is planning to release two types of AI-powered glasses, with the first pair expected to launch in 2026, featuring built-in speakers, microphones, and cameras, and the second pair adding an in-lens display showing real-time data.

### Detailed Points
- The Slop Evader browser extension is available for download on Chrome and Firefox, allowing users to search the pre-AI internet and avoid AI-generated content.
- President Trump's executive order aims to establish national rules for AI, with the "AI Litigation Task Force" tasked with challenging existing state AI laws and promoting national standards.
- Google's AI-powered glasses will feature Gemini, allowing users to interact with the AI through built-in speakers, microphones, and cameras, with the second pair adding an in-lens display for real-time data.
- IBM has released a playbook detailing 3 challenges and approaches to help boost the impact of agentic AI, emphasizing the importance of aligning AI with workflows, creating a clear AI plan, and integrating AI with existing tools.
- Researchers have analyzed 306 deployed AI agents, identifying a roadmap for success, including keeping workflows simple and controlled, using off-the-shelf models, and having humans in the loop.
- RAD Intel has launched an award-winning tech product, with $60M+ raised, recurring 7-figure contracts, and 2x sales from last year, offering a unique solution for businesses.

newsletters.subject: ai got the job
newsletters.summary:
## Staying Ahead with AI

### Key Highlights
- Opus 4.5 and Gemini 3, two new AI models, have been released with significant improvements in coding capabilities.
- Opus 4.5 achieved 80.9% on SWE-bench Verified, outperforming other models like Sonnet 4.5 and GPT-5.1-Codex-Max.
- The model uses 76% fewer output tokens than Sonnet 4.5, resulting in lower costs and faster responses.
- Opus 4.5 is priced at $5 per million input tokens and $25 per million output tokens, a 67% price cut from the previous version.

### Detailed Points
- Two real-world tests were conducted to compare the performance of Opus 4.5 and Gemini 3: a Django monolith migration and a production database crisis.
- Opus 4.5 provided more comprehensive and detailed responses, including working code, Bash scripts, and SQL queries, whereas Gemini 3 provided more general advice.
- The tests demonstrated that Opus 4.5 can complete tasks that would take humans hours or days to finish, making it a valuable tool for developers.
- However, the model is still the most expensive option, and its use cases are limited to specific scenarios such as architecture decisions, complex debugging, and feature scoping.
- The release of Opus 4.5 and Gemini 3 marks a shift in the AI landscape, where models are no longer just assistants but can now complete tasks independently.

newsletters.subject: Lightweight Gaussian Process-Based Visual Servoing for Autonomous Wheelchair Sidewalk Navigation
newsletters.summary:
## JournalClub.io Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- Researchers from King Faisal University, led by Hafez et al., have developed a lightweight Gaussian Process-Based Visual Servoing system for autonomous wheelchair sidewalk navigation.
- The system uses a simple camera, a Raspberry Pi, and an actuator to navigate tactile paving lines in real-time with minimal error.
- The approach is based on visual servoing, a robotics technique that treats camera images as the primary feedback signal for control.
- The system learned to predict turning commands directly from image features using a Gaussian Process model, bypassing the need for explicit Jacobian calculation.

### Detailed Points
- Tactile paving, also known as tactile guidance, is a surface feature designed to help people with visual impairments detect their surroundings and navigate safely.
- The authors' system uses a monocular camera to detect tactile paving edges and steer the wheelchair accordingly, running on low-cost hardware.
- The Gaussian Process model achieves faster inference times on a Raspberry Pi compared to neural network alternatives, making it suitable for real-time control.
- The system was tested on a commercial wheelchair equipped with a Raspberry Pi, a camera, and a motor driver, and demonstrated strong performance in navigating a 100-meter sidewalk segment.
- The system's limitations include its reliance on the presence of tactile paving, but the framework can be extended to incorporate additional visual features.
- The authors prioritize practical deployment considerations, making the system accessible to a broader audience without significant cost barriers.

### Important Links
- **Read the Original Paper**: https://journalclub.io/track/yfNAsF62WxbRhT6edsdybdliladfO9w6K9MWccz6HZXpsvB8jW (direct link to the research paper)
- **Watch or Listen to the Episode**: https://journalclub.io/episodes/lightweight-gaussian-process-based-visual-servoing-for-autonomous-wheelchair-sidewalk-navigation?token=0wZUgYj8uIbwFjszusoOp6iHpU6E5wvQeE9RFtioXFYM8YeFjz (link to the podcast/video episode discussing the paper)
- **Privacy**: https://journalclub.io/track/YZTdvbiRw0QcULfmvgzKCcOsoZilnWjmZTH3AGiGB2uZdOk1oT (link to JournalClub.io's privacy policy)
- **Preferences**: https://journalclub.io/track/W3RtcHg7MVyBTjENCJxuY5MJTtSpRDY9JSPE6UUVivB7m8xAef (link to manage email notification preferences)

Lightweight Gaussian Process-Based Visual Servoing for Autonomous Wheelchair Sidewalk Navigation   

That surface is called "tactile paving". Most of us take it for granted, but it's actually very important. Itâ€™s designed to help people with visual impairments detect where they are and whatâ€™s coming next. Those raised bumps and ridges act like a code. A grid of small domes signals a hazard or a place to stop, like the edge of a curb, a train platform, or a crosswalk.

![](https://journalclub.io/px/g8rdC8SqyaGBkXHlGEdxVIHCJNbEyvBdYtocGFlDa27xbmxi2w)

newsletters.subject: LlamaIndex Newsletter 2025-12-09
newsletters.summary:
## LlamaIndex Newsletter 2025-12-09

### Key Highlights
- LlamaIndex is seeking feedback from early users of LlamaAgents and LlamaSheets through feedback calls, with participants being entered into a raffle for $50 gift cards.
- The newsletter highlights significant updates including automated spreadsheet analysis with LlamaSheets, async PDF processing capabilities, and one-click agent deployment.
- A deep dive into OCR benchmarking analysis is provided, discussing the strengths and limitations of OlmOCR-Bench for real-world document parsing.

### Detailed Points
- **Call for Feedback:** LlamaIndex is collecting feedback from early users of LlamaAgents and LlamaSheets. Users can schedule calls to share their experiences and use cases, with the incentive of being entered into a raffle for $50 gift cards.
- **Automated Spreadsheet Analysis:** LlamaSheets allows for the automation of spreadsheet analysis using coding agents to extract clean data from messy Excel files. Tutorials are provided on how to set up coding agents like Claude and Cursor to work with LlamaSheets-extracted parquet files.
- **Async PDF Processing:** LlamaParse now supports async processing of PDFs, enabling users to parse multiple PDFs efficiently. A tutorial is available on how to use async processing to parse entire folders, control concurrency, and get detailed progress tracking.
- **One-Click Agent Deployment:** LlamaCloud offers one-click deployment of production-ready agent workflows. Users can choose from pre-built templates, configure secrets, and deploy in under 3 minutes with automatic building and hosting.
- **OCR Benchmarking Analysis:** The newsletter links to a blog post analyzing OlmOCR-Bench, discussing its strengths, limitations, benchmark bias, test brittleness, and the future of document parsing evaluation.
- **LlamaCloud Updates:** LlamaCloud is the gateway to smarter automation, offering various tools and features for AI and tech development. Enterprises building with LlamaIndex can get in touch for sneak peeks at upcoming products and to discuss partnerships.
- **Community and Support:** The LlamaIndex community is invited to join the Discord channel for live discussions and support. Links to GitHub, Twitter, LinkedIn, and YouTube are also provided for staying updated on the latest developments and releases.

newsletters.summary:
## TLDR AI

### Key Highlights
- OpenAI released a comprehensive report on the state of enterprise AI, highlighting its adoption and benefits.
- Claude Code is now available in Slack, enabling developers to run coding sessions directly from threads.
- Alignment research is crucial for achieving Artificial General Intelligence (AGI).
- Lovable achieved $80M ARR in 7 months with a lean team and experiments with pricing models.
- NVIDIA's H200 AI chip sales to China will be allowed with a 25% revenue cut for the US.

### Detailed Points
- OpenAI's report shares insights on enterprise AI adoption, worker benefits, and organizational leaders' experiences, drawing from real-world usage data and a survey of 9,000 workers.
- Claude Code in Slack integrates AI deeper into team collaboration, allowing for workflow automation, repo context detection, and progress updates.
- Alignment research is part of the core research problem, and labs that treat alignment as a constraint will hit a ceiling, while those that figure out how to build models understanding human values will pull ahead.
- Lovable's success can be attributed to its experimental pricing models, such as token pricing, outcome-based value, and hybrid models, which are becoming increasingly important for AI companies.
- NVIDIA's H200 AI chip sales to China will be allowed under the condition that the US receives a 25% cut, aiming to support American jobs and manufacturing.
- Other notable developments include the launch of adk_rust, a framework for developing and deploying AI agents in Rust, and the prediction that AI will make formal verification go mainstream.
- Trump has promised an executive order to block state AI regulations, which could have significant implications for the industry.
- The newsletter also covers various research papers and articles on topics such as AI security, misaligned completions, and the potential of AI to disrupt traditional industries.

newsletters.subject: ChatGPT is becoming the office default
newsletters.summary:
## Mindstream

### Key Highlights
- OpenAI reports strong growth in enterprise use of its tools, with ChatGPT message volume rising eightfold since November 2024.
- Meta acquires AI startup Limitless, which will stop selling its AI pendant device and end support after one year.
- Paramount launches a $108.4 billion hostile takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery.

### Detailed Points
- OpenAI has released new data showing a significant increase in the use of its tools by companies, with ChatGPT message volume rising eightfold since November 2024. This growth indicates that more businesses are adopting AI solutions for their operations.
- According to the Ramp AI Index, 36% of U.S. businesses using enterprise AI tools now choose ChatGPT Enterprise, compared to 14.3% using Anthropic. Custom GPTs have increased 19x and now make up 20% of enterprise messages.
- OpenAI says these tools save workers 40â€“60 minutes a day, and companies are using AI more deeply, with use of â€œreasoning tokensâ€ increasing 320 times year-on-year.
- Meta has acquired Limitless, an AI startup that made a wearable device called an AI pendant. The device recorded conversations, but Limitless will stop selling it and end support after one year.
- Limitless will also shut down some features, including Rewind, a desktop tool that recorded activity and made it searchable. The company will no longer collect subscription fees.
- Meta is expanding its AI wearables team by bringing Limitless in-house. The acquisition aligns with Metaâ€™s goal of building AI wearables, particularly smart glasses.
- Paramount has launched a $108.4 billion hostile takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, calling Netflixâ€™s existing $83 billion offer â€œinferiorâ€ and warning it would face long, messy regulatory hurdles.
- The bid covers all of Warner Bros. Discovery, including its linear TV networks, and offers $18 billion more in cash than Netflixâ€™s offer.
- Other notable news includes the detection of a new mpox strain in England, the cancellation of the game Postal: Bullet Paradise, and the return of The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring to cinemas in January 2026.

newsletters.subject: How to Log 1M Events/Sec Without Slowing Down Your System
newsletters.summary:
## Skilled Coder Newsletter

### Key Highlights
- The newsletter discusses the challenges of logging 1 million events per second without slowing down a system.
- It highlights the importance of logging in modern systems, citing examples from fintech, ad-tech, and gaming.
- The author emphasizes that logging must be asynchronous, streamed, and decoupled from the application to achieve scalability.

### Detailed Points
- Logging is not as simple as it looks, as it involves I/O, storage, latency, durability, retention, indexing, and retrieval.
- The newsletter explores four attempts to log 1M events/sec: logging directly inside app code, batching logs, logging to a database, and sending logs directly to Elasticsearch/OpenSearch.
- Each attempt is explained, along with its limitations and why it fails at scale.
- The author proposes a scalable architecture that includes non-blocking logging, a queue or stream (e.g., Kafka, Pulsar, Kinesis), and a storage layer with hot, warm, and cold storage.
- The importance of observability and using metrics over logs when possible is also discussed.
- The author mentions various tools and technologies, including Logback, Disruptor, Zerolog, Pino, Tracing, Prometheus, OpenTelemetry, and Grafana Tempo.
- The newsletter provides an example architecture diagram and explains the benefits of this approach, including asynchronous logging, scalable storage, and observability.
- The author also discusses potential follow-up questions, such as avoiding log duplication, detecting ingestion lag, and handling sensitive data.

newsletters.subject: ChatGPT Built Me a $8K/Month Business (I Still Don't Have a Website)
newsletters.summary:
## Daily ChatGPT

### Key Highlights
- The newsletter shares a success story of building an $8,000/month business using ChatGPT and LinkedIn without a website.
- It highlights the potential of leveraging AI for business optimization and client acquisition.
- A simple daily routine and specific ChatGPT prompts are credited for the success.

### Detailed Points
- The success story started with identifying a skill (in this case, expertise in Excel) and using ChatGPT to package it into services that people would pay for.
- The services included Excel Automation Audit, Custom Dashboard Build, Team Training Package, and Monthly Optimization, priced at $500, $1,500, $2,000, and $800/month, respectively.
- ChatGPT was used to generate LinkedIn posts, case studies, and responses to prospects, saving time and increasing efficiency.
- A daily routine of 1 hour, including 15 minutes for creating and publishing a LinkedIn post, 20 minutes for checking DMs and responding to comments, and 25 minutes for engaging with target customers, was followed.
- The importance of focusing on a specific target audience (Series A startup CFOs) and avoiding common mistakes like trying to help everyone, apologizing for prices, and customizing everything, was emphasized.
- The use of specific ChatGPT prompts, such as the "Skill Monetizer," "LinkedIn Authority Builder," and "Problem Finder," was crucial in generating leads and closing deals.
- Real client acquisition examples were provided, showcasing the effectiveness of the strategy.
- Month-by-month revenue growth was shared, demonstrating the potential for rapid business scaling using this approach.
- A free bonus guide, "30 CREATIVE WAYS TO USE AI FOR BUSINESS OPTIMIZATION," is offered to subscribers who reply with "Biz" to the email.
